Medics share the spoils in two feisty encounters

27/02/2011

The Hull Medics enjoyed the better of the Medics football, taking two points to York's one (Thumbnail credit Image: Peter Iveson)

Image by

By undefined undefined

UNIVERSITY OF YORK MEDICS FIRSTS 2 UNIVERSITY OF HULL MEDICS FIRSTS 3 York Medics closely missed out on another Varsity point in a close loss to Hull. It was a scrappy encounter mainly due to the poor state of the pitch but both teams did their best in the poor conditions available to them. Unfortunately for the few spectators on the side-line skill was lost in return for a quick and physical game. York got off to a very poor start as Stu Haldon, in trying to clear the ball, struck it against the Hull striker whose pace saw him run clear through on goal and strike a powerful shot into the roof of the York goal. York then came close to a quick equaliser, but Matt Cullen couldn't direct his header goalwards following a good run and cross from winger Luke Thornton. Thornton was then guilty of missing a guilt-edge chance after Cullen this time turned provider with a precise through ball to his feet. As the previously deserted burger van gradually gained more custom the York team pressed the Hullgoal further and had a succession of strong shots saved by the Hull goalkeeper. At the end of the first-halfhowever, against the run of play Hull gained a penalty as Andy McCormick slid in to take the legs of the Hull striker following a very accurate through ball by Sam Botchey. The penalty was saved by Dan Callingham but the rebound bounced straight back to the feet of the taker and he slid the ball into the empty net to make it 2-0. York were then very quick to reply and they pulled themselves back into the game following yet another penalty as Cullen was brought down in the area. Captain Matt Fortnam was put in charge of pulling a goal back and he struck his effort hard and low past the helpless Hull goalkeeper to make the score 2-1 as the teams went into half-time. As the start of the second half began Luke Thornton went down with cramp early and had to be replaced by substitute Matt Nelson. This proved to be the perfect symbol for the state of the pitch as it grew heavier and heavier leading to a more and more scrappy game which became dominated by strong tackles. As this happened the spectators were kept amused and well fed by the people walking around selling cakes, which helped towards creating a good and lively atmosphere from the side-lines. With ten minutes left Hull went 3-1 up following a very suspect decision from the referee which ruled the Hull player onside when the York defence clearly felt differently as they all stopped waiting for the free kick to be given. Matt Fortnam then scored his second as he managed to bundle the ball over the line and force the match into a tight and tense finish. Unfortunately the York team couldn't force an equaliser and the game finished 3-2 to the Hull medics. Two goal York hero and captain Matt Fortnam commented after the match that the "game was played in good spirit but Hull were more up for it on the day and deserved their win" which summed the encounter up perfectly. In such poor conditions and on such a heavy pitch it was always going to be the more physical team that gained the upper hand. Image: Peter Iveson UNIVERSITY OF YORK MEDICS SECONDS 3 UNIVERSITY OF HULL MEDICS SECONDS 2 A late goal by Mo Patel meant the York Medics Seconds took the one Varsity point on offer after overcoming their Hull Medic rivals by a score of 3-2. York Medics dominated the match from start to finish, and really should have won by a much more comfortable margin. The home side went in front through goals from Taylor Messenger and Jonny Pawson and could have added three or four more in the first half. Hull medics' defence struggled to deal with their opposition all game and had York's finishing been better they would have been out of sight at half-time. The Medics' fixture, apparently played every year, was quite feisty but York's organisation and talent was clear for all to see. Unbelievably the game turned after the break. A foul by York's star man, Paddy Campbell, gave Hull a chance to level from the spot and Faran Vela stepped up to half the deficit. The game then became quite chaotic as both sides benefited from some lax defending. York's Will Bansema could have ended the game as a contest with two good chances but failed to add a third for his side on both occasions and, despite their domination from the first whistle, Hull equalised with five minutes to play. A bouncing ball found its way to Mo Asraghi in the box and he put it away to make it 2-2 and set up a tense finish. Both sides pushed forward but it was Patel who made the difference as he slammed home with his left foot from just inside the area. York medics' captain, Tom Morris, was delighted with the win and also particularly happy to be involved with White Rose Varsity: "It's great to get involved with Varsity with the whole Uni. We've been playing this fixture for five years and it's always great to beat Hull".
